awd_titl_txt: LTREB:   Long-term behavioral and genetic analyses of a wild primate population
awd_abstract_narration:
The long-term objective in this study is to develop a comprehensive picture of how behavior shapes population dynamics and individual life history outcomes in one population of wild mammals, the savanna baboons of the Amboseli basin in east Africa. The overall conceptual framework is concerned with how behavior affects survival and reproduction across the life time, as well as how behavior affects physiology and population genetics.  Throughout their long-term work, the investigators have focused on a series of short-term goals that represent components of their long-term objective. With this LTREB project they overtly reach toward one longer-term goal. Specifically, they will follow the ongoing process of genetic admixture (hybridization) between a study population of primarily yellow baboons and neighboring populations of anubis (olive) baboons (a separate subspecies) in order to understand the way in which behavior impacts, and is in turn affected by hybridization. Their previous work has documented rather dramatic differences between hybrid and yellow baboons. This represents a unique opportunity to follow a natural process of population admixture over time, and to test hypotheses about its behavioral causes and consequences. This project is relevant to understanding speciation because of the role that hybridization can play in speciation. It is also relevant to understanding human evolution because of the close ecological parallels between baboons and humans, and the similarity between the baboon radiation in Africa and the evolutionary history of various human species. 
The proposed project will continue the investigators' long history of training American and Kenyan students, activities that are intimately connected with the research goals. Recent integration of research and education has focused on training for 13 post-doctoral fellows, 12 doctoral candidates, 5 Master's Degree students, 34 undergraduates, and 2 high school students. The investigators also actively collaborate with Kenyan scientists and are working with them on in-country capacity building.

por.por_cntn:
Hybridization— occurring in at least 10% of animal species and 25% of plant species—is among the most important sources of evolutionary novelty in natural populations, and directly affects both speciation and adaptation. Most studies describe hybridization at the population level, rather than describing fitness outcomes for hybrid individuals. Understanding the effects of hybridization for individuals is crucial for understanding gene flow between taxa, and the rare detailed descriptions of how hybridization affects individuals often serve as flagship examples of evolution in action.

 

The goal of this study was to evaluate exactly how hybridization affects individual maturation, social behavior, and reproduction in a wild population of yellow baboons in Amboseli, Kenya, which hybridizes with neighboring populations of anubis baboons. This project is part of a 10-year research plan that has been enabled by this unusual and important NSF funding mechanism, the LTREB program (Long-term Research in Environmental Biology).  The PI leads an international team of American and Kenyan researchers, and the project has contributed to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

 

Under this award, we have shown that hybridization in wild baboons (genetic mixing between two adjacent baboon species) is regulated by social and sexual behavior, and that hybridization in turn has effects on how individuals develop and behave. Specifically, hybrid males reached puberty and adult dominance rank status earlier, and dispersed earlier, than ‘pure’ yellow males. In females, age at puberty was slightly earlier among hybrids, but hybridity had no detectable effect on other maturational milestones, such as age at adult dominance status or age at first birth. Instead, the most important predictors of female maturation were maternal and family characteristics like maternal dominance rank and family size. This male-female difference suggests that, for females, the effects of genetic background (i.e., hybridization) on maturation are modified by maternal characteristics, which are a potent component of the environment for baboons.

 

Hybridization also affected two aspects of mating behavior in Amboseli baboons. First, pairs in which the male and female were both yellow-like baboons or both anubis-like were more likely to mate, although this pattern of ‘assortative mating’ has clearly not been strong enough to prevent multiple generations of hybrids in this population. Second, hybrid males experienced a mating advantage over yellow males, and were more likely to sire offspring. Our working hypothesis was that the hybrid male mating and paternity advantage was caused by a hybrid advantage in attaining high dominance rank. However, this hypothesis was not supported; hybridity did not account for dominance rank. This raises the question of how the hybrid male mating advantage arises, a major question in our renewal application for this award.

 

Hybrid baboons can be found in several areas to the northwest and southeast of Amboseli, but the active hybrid zone is relatively narrow, perhaps 100 km wide. Studies of this hybrid zone indicate a bias in the direction of hybridization: anubis males are more successful at reproducing in yellow groups than yellow males are at reproducing in anubis groups. This finding is extremely interesting in light of the earlier maturation and mating advantages (described above) that hybrid males experience; our renewal application for this grant proposes to examine this phenomenon in more detail.
